member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.GetQCDSlack(ILOG.Concert.IRange)
member.summary: Returns the dual slack vector of a quadratic constraint in a quadratically constrained program (QCP).

remarks.p: This method returns a linear expression representing the dual slack vector of the quadratic constraint rng. The returned expression contains only the nonzero coefficients of the dual slack vector.
remarks.exception: UnknownObjectException The range constraint rng is not in the active model.
ILOG.Concert.Exception If the method fails, an exception of type ILOG.Concert.Exception, or one of its derived classes, is thrown.

member.param: The quadratic constraint for which the dual slack vector is queried.
member.returns: A linear expression describing the dual slack vector for rng.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.CopyVMConfig(System.String)
member.summary: Reads a virtual machine configuration from a string.
member.remarks:
The argument xmlString must be a string conforming to the VMC file format. If xmlString can be parsed successfully, then the specified configuration is installed into this instance. In case of error, a previously installed virtual machine configuration remains unchanged.
If a virtual machine configuration is installed into an instance of this class, and the model to be solved is a MIP, then the solve method of this instance uses parallel distributed MIP to solve the problem.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if xmlString cannot be parsed or if there is not enough memory to allocate the configuration.
member.param: The string containing the VMC configuration.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ReadVMConfig(System.String)
member.summary: Reads a virtual machine configuration from a file.
member.remarks:
The function reads the virtual machine configuration in file (which must be in the VMC file format). If file can be parsed successfully, then the specified configuration is installed into this instance. In case of error, a previously installed virtual machine configuration remains unchanged.
If a virtual machine configuration is installed into an instance of this class, and the model to be solved is a MIP, then the solve method of this instance uses parallel distributed MIP to solve the problem.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if xmlString cannot be parsed, or if there is not enough memory to allocate the configuration.
member.param: The name of the file containing the VMC configuration.

member.param: Name of output file.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ReadAnnotations(System.String)
member.summary: Reads annotations from a file.
member.remarks:
See the topic Annotating a model for CPLEX in the CPLEX User's Manual for a sample of the header of an annotation file. See the sample UFL_25_35_1 distributed with the product for an example of an annotated model.
Important: CPLEX deletes existing annotations before CPLEX attempts to read filename. Consequently, all currently existing annotations are deleted even if reading fails.
Because indicator constraints are not top-level modeling objects in Concert, this method ignores annotations for indicator constraints in filename. More specifically, upon input, this method resets the annotation for any indicator constraint to its default value.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if the file could not be read, was corrupt, or annotations could not be constructed.
member.param: Input file name.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.WriteBendersAnnotation(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the annotation of the decompostion CPLEX automatically generates for the model of the CPLEX problem object to the specified file.
member.remarks: Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if file cannot be written or there is no automatic Benders decomposition.
member.param: Name of output file.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Var2ind(ILOG.Concert.INumVar[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts an array of INumVar instances to the respective set of indices in the current model.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Use(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Function,System.Int64)
member.summary: Register or clear a callback to be invoked by CPLEX during optimization.
member.remarks:
Call this with callback = null or contextMask = 0 to clear the current callback.
To register a callback invoke this method with callback argument different from null and a contextMask different from 0 (zero). The value of contextMask can be the bitwise OR of values from Callback.Context.Id.
Note: The function will always clear any current callback, even if setting the new callback fails. Thus at most one callback can be registered with a single instance of Cplex.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.
member.param: The new callback to be set or null to clear the callback.
A bitmask that specifies in which contexts to invoke the callback or 0 (zero) to clear the callback.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Use(ILOG.CPLEX.ModelingAssistance.Callback)
member.summary: Register or clear a modeling assistance callback.
member.remarks:
During optimization, CPLEX will invoke the callback with information about a particular modeling assistance warning. Call this with callback = null to clear the current callback. To register a callback, provide this method with a non-null callback.
The callback will only be invoked if the CPLEX parameter Cplex.Param.Read.DataCheck is set to Cplex.DataCheck.Assist. In addition, the parameter Cplex.Param.Read.WarningLimit controls the number of times each type of modeling assistance warning will be reported (the rest will be ignored). See CPX_PARAM_DATACHECK and CPX_PARAM_WARNLIM in the Parameters of CPLEX Reference Manual.
Note: The function will always clear any current callback, even if setting the new callback fails. Thus at most one callback can be registered with a single instance of Cplex.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.
member.param: The new callback to be set or null to clear the callback.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.StaticLex(ILOG.Concert.INumExpr[],System.Double[],System.Int32[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.String)
member.summary: This function defines a multi-criterion expression for lexicographic ordering.

remarks.p: A lexicographic ordering means that any improvement of a criterion with higher priority is more important than any improvement of a lower priority criterion.
All of the arguments, except for criteria will accept null.
Note: A shallow copy of criteria will be made when passed to this method. Thus, after calling this method, any modifications to criteria should be avoided.

member.param: an array of numerical expressions.
specifies weights by which to multiply the expression of the corresponding criterion in criteria. This argument can be null in which case, the weights will default to 1.0 (one).

each criterion is assigned the priority specified by the corresponding entry in this array. This argument can be null, in which case, priorities are implicitly assigned by the order in which the criteria are specified in criteria. For example, if n criteria are passed in, then the first criterion will be given a priority of n - 1, the second criterion will be given a priority of n - 2, and so on, until the last criterion is given a priority of 0.
specifies the absolute tolerance to be used when solving for a criterion. This argument can be null, in which case, the absolute tolerances will default to 0.0 (zero).
specifies the relative tolerance to be used when solving for a criterion. This argument can be null, in which case, the relative tolerances will default to 0.0 (zero).
the name for the new multi-criterion expression. This argument can be null, in which case, the name will be set to null.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.StaticLex(ILOG.Concert.INumExpr[],System.String)
member.summary: This function defines a multi-criterion expression for lexicographic ordering.

remarks.p: A lexicographic ordering means that any improvement of a criterion with higher priority is more important than any improvement of a lower priority criterion.
Note: A shallow copy of criteria will be made when passed to this method. Thus, after calling this method, any modifications to criteria should be avoided.

member.param: an array of numerical expressions.
the name for the new multi-criterion expression. This argument can be null, in which case, the name will be set to null.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.StaticLex(ILOG.Concert.INumExpr[])
member.summary: This function defines a multi-criterion expression for lexicographic ordering.

remarks.p: A lexicographic ordering means that any improvement of a criterion with higher priority is more important than any improvement of a lower priority criterion.

member.param: an array of numerical expressions.

member.name: P:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Ncols
member.summary: Gets the number of columns in the matrix representation of the active model. Note that the result may be greater than the number of variables in the active model, since some modeling objects may require more than one matrix column.

member.name: P:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Nrows
member.summary: Gets the number of rows in the matrix representation of the active model. The result may be different from the number of constraints in the active model, since some modeling objects may require more than one matrix row and quadratic constraints are not accounted for as rows.

member.name: P:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.NQCs
member.summary: Gets the number of quadratic constraints in the active model. The result may be different from the number of constraints in the active model, since linear constraints are counted separately.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status
member.summary: Enumeration of possible solution status values, as returned by the method cplex.GetStatus.

remarks.p: The status contains the information the Cplex optimizer has gathered so far about a possible solution to the active model. User code typically refers to a solution status by specifying the full path, for example Cplex.Status.Optimal.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Error
member.summary: The Error solution status reports that an error has occurred.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Unknown
member.summary: The Unknown solution status reports that the optimizer has not gathered any information about the active model.

remarks.p: This is usually the status before a solve method has been called, or after the model has been manipulated.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Feasible
member.summary: The Feasible solution status reports that the Cplex optimizer has found a feasible solution that can be queried with the method getValue.

remarks.p: Neither the optimality nor the nonoptimality of this solution has been proven.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Bounded
member.summary: The Bounded solution status reports that the Cplex optimizer has determined that the model is not unbounded.

remarks.p: This status does not imply that the model is feasible.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Optimal
member.summary: The Optimal solution status reports that the Cplex optimizer has found an optimal solution that can be queried with the method getValue.

remarks.p: The solution is proven to be optimal only within tolerances and achievable numeric accuracy.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Infeasible
member.summary: The Infeasible solution status reports that the Cplex optimizer has determined that the model is infeasible.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.Unbounded
member.summary: The Unbounded solution status reports that the Cplex optimizer has determined that the model is unbounded.

remarks.p: It has not, however, found the model to be feasible. Instead, the optimizer has proven that for any feasible solution, a better one could be constructed.
In order to check whether the model is feasible, remove the objective function and re-optimize.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.InfeasibleOrUnbounded
member.summary: The InfeasibleOrUnbounded solution status reports that the Cplex optimizer has determined that the model is infeasible or unbounded.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Status.ToString
member.summary: Transforms status into a human-readable string.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm
member.summary: Enumeration of types of algorithms (algorithm-type) used by Cplex.

remarks.p: Use these algorithm-types with the parameters Cplex.IntParam.RootAlg, and Cplex.IntParam.NodeAlg, to specify which algorithm to apply during branch-and-cut search. In the case of Cplex.IntParam.RootAlg, the algorithm-type specifies the algorithm that solves the root relaxation. In the case of Cplex.IntParam.NodeAlg, the algorithm-type specifies the algorithm that solves the problems at other nodes. These parameters can be set with the method Cplex.SetParam.
These algorithm-types are also returned by Cplex.GetAlgorithm to report the algorithm that was used to generate the current solution.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.None
member.summary: Selects no algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type is available only to specify the crossover algorithm to use after an LP or QP is solved with the barrier method. If you select Cplex.Algorithm.None as the crossover algorithm for the barrier method (parameter Cplex.IntParam.BarCrossAlg), no crossover to a simplex solution is performed after the barrier optimization.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Auto
member.summary: Allows Cplex to select an algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm choice instructs the Cplex optimizer to select the most suitable or default optimizer for solving LPs, QCPs, or QPs.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Primal
member.summary: Selects the primal simplex algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type instructs the Cplex optimizer to use the primal simplex method for solving LPs or QPs.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Dual
member.summary: Selects the dual simplex algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type instructs the Cplex optimizer to use the dual simplex method for solving LPs or QPs.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Network
member.summary: Selects the network simplex algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type instructs the Cplex optimizer to use the network simplex method on the embedded network for solving LPs or QPs and to continue with a simplex method.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Barrier
member.summary: Selects the barrier algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type instructs the Cplex optimizer to use the barrier optimizer to solve an LP, QCP, or QP. When solving an LP or QP, the optimizer performs a crossover to a simplex solution unless the parameter Cplex.IntParam.BarCrossAlg is set to Cplex.Algorithm.None.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Sifting
member.summary: Selects the sifting algorithm.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type instructs the Cplex optimizer to use the sifting optimizer to solve LP problems. The sifting optimizer is available only for LPs; other attempts to use this choice will automatically revert to Auto.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.Concurrent
member.summary: Selects the concurrent optimizer.

remarks.p: This algorithm-type instructs the Cplex optimizer to use several algorithm options concurrently.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.FeasOpt
member.summary: This value may not be used to select an optimizer but is returned by Cplex.GetAlgorithm when the method feasOpt has generated the current solution.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Algorithm.MIP
member.summary: This value may not be used to select an optimizer but is returned by Cplex.GetAlgorithm when the mixed integer optimizer has generated the current solution.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet
member.summary: A parameter set for Cplex.

remarks.p: This class allows you to store and restore parameters not at their default values.
Cplex.ParameterSet objects can be created empty with the constructor and then modified. They can also be created by the method Cplex.GetParameterSet.
A parameter set can be applied to an instance of Cplex by means of Cplex.SetParameterSet(set).

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.Clear
member.summary: Clears the parameter set.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.SetParam(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.IntParam,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets an integer parameter to value val.
member.param: The identifier of the parameter to set.
The new value for the integer parameter.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.SetParam(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.LongParam,System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets an integer parameter to value val.
member.param: The identifier of the parameter to set.
The new value for the integer parameter.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.SetParam(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.StringParam,System.String)
member.summary: Sets a string parameter to value val.
member.param: The identifier of the string parameter to set.
The new value for the string parameter.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.SetParam(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BooleanParam,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets a Boolean parameter to value val.
member.param: The identifier of the Boolean parameter to be set.
The new value for the Boolean parameter.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.SetParam(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.DoubleParam,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets a double parameter to value val.
member.param: The identifier of the double parameter to be set.
The new value for the double parameter

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ParameterSet.GetParam(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.IntParam)

remarks.exception: ILOG.Concert.Exception If the method fails, an exception of type ILOG.Concert.Exception, or one of its derived classes, is thrown.

member.param: The identifier of the integer parameter to be queried.
member.returns: The current value of the integer parameter.

summary.p: Enumeration of possible values for the delete mode of Cplex, as controlled by the methods setDeleteMode and getDeleteMode.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.DeleteMode.LeaveBasis
member.summary: Sets leave basis as the delete mode.

remarks.p: If the delete mode is set to Cplex.DeleteMode.LeaveBasis, an existing basis will remain unchanged if variables or constraints are removed from the loaded LP model. This situation may render the basis unusable for restarting optimization on the modified LP.
If no basis is present in the invoking object, the setting of the delete mode has no effect.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.DeleteMode.FixBasis
member.summary: Sets fix basis as the delete mode.

remarks.p: If the delete mode is set to Cplex.DeleteMode.FixBasis, the invoking object will do basis pivots in order to maintain a valid basis when variables or constraints are removed. This situation makes the delete operation more computation intensive, but it may provide a better starting point for reoptimization after the modification of the active model.
If no basis is present in the invoking object, the setting of the delete mode has no effect.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus
member.summary: Enumeration of possible basis status codes.

remarks.p: A basis captures the essence of a solution of the simplex algorithm and can be used, among other things, to warm start an optimization with the simplex algorithm. The class Cplex.BasisStatus distinguishes three nonbasic statuses and one basic status for the variables (columns) and constraints (rows) of an LP or QP.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.NotABasicStatus
member.summary: This status represents an illegal basis status.

remarks.p: No valid basis may contain such a status.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.AtLower
member.summary: This status reports that the variable or slack corresponding to a constraint is nonbasic and at its bound.

remarks.p: In cases where the variable has both finite upper and lower bounds, this status means that the variable is set to its lower bound.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.Basic
member.summary: This status reports that the variable or slack corresponding to a constraint is basic.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.AtUpper
member.summary: This status reports that the variable or slack corresponding to a constraint is nonbasic, and at its upper bound.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.FreeOrSuperbasic
member.summary: This status reports that the variable is nonbasic, but not at a bound.

remarks.p: Either the variable is free and set to 0 (zero) or it is set to a specific value as a super-basic variable.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.ToString
member.summary: Transforms the status into a human-readable string.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BasisStatus.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: This method can be use to test whether two basis statuses are equal.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.WriteLevel

remarks.p: Use these levels of detail to set the Cplex.IntParam.WriteLevel parameter.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.WriteLevel.Auto

to add, access, or change a MIP start.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPStartEffort.CheckFeas

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPStartEffort.SolveMIP

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPStartEffort.Repair
member.summary: CPLEX attempts to repair the MIP start, if it is infeasible, according to the RepairTries parameter.

member.summary: CPLEX accepts the MIP start without any checks.
member.remarks: The MIP start needs to be complete.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Relaxation
member.summary: Enumeration of possible values for the parameter FeasOptMode.

remarks.p: This parameter controls several aspects of how the method Cplex.FeasOpt performs its relaxation.

The method feasOpt works in two phases. In its first phase, it attempts to find a minimum-cost relaxation of a given infeasible model. If you want feasOpt to stop after this first phase, choose a value with Min in its symbolic name. If you want feasOpt to continue beyond its first phase and find a solution that is optimal with respect to the original objective function, subject to the constraint that the cost of the relaxation must not exceed the minimum value found in the first phase, choose a value with Opt in its symbolic name.
In both phases, the suffixes Sum, Inf, and Quad specify the relaxation cost metric:

ul.li: Sum tells feasOpt to minimize the weighted sum of the required relaxations of bounds and constraints.
Inf tells feasOpt to minimize the number of bounds and constraints that are relaxed.
Quad tells feasOpt to minimize the weighted sum of the squares of required relaxations of bounds and constraints.

remarks.p: Weights are determined by the preference values provided as input to the method feasOpt.

When the method and is used to group constraints as input to feasOpt, the relaxation is computed on groups instead of on individual constraints. For example, all constraints in a group can be relaxed for a total cost of one unit under the various Inf metrics.

member.summary: = CPX_FEASOPT_MIN_SUM

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Relaxation.OptSum
member.summary: = CPX_FEASOPT_OPT_SUM

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Relaxation.MinInf
member.summary: = CPX_FEASOPT_MIN_INF

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Relaxation.OptInf

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.QualityType
member.summary: This class contains symbolic names to identify measures of the quality of a solution.
member.remarks: These measures can be queried from the method Cplex.GetQuality. These solution quality measures pertain either to characteristics of the computed solution or to the accuracy measures of the computed solution. When the name of the solution quality measure begins with Max, that measure identifies a constraint or a variable associated with the requested solution quality measure. For example, if you pass the solution quality measure MaxPi to the method Cplex.GetQuality, the result is an instance of IRange with the largest dual value (that is, a characteristic of the solution) among the constraints in the model specified by the Cplex object. Similarly, the solution quality measure MaxIntInfeas causes the method Cplex.GetQuality to return an instance of INumVar with the largest integrality violation (that is, a measure of accuracy) in the computed solution. For these solution quality measures, the variable or range returned is the first variable or range that attains the maximal associated quality value.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Quality
member.summary: Objects of this class contain information computed to measure the quality of a solution.

remarks.p: The possible quality measures are declared in Cplex.QualityType. A quality object is returned by the method Cplex.GetQuality. The returned quality object contains its type and the numeric value of the requested quality measure. For many quality measures, the value is attained at a specific constraint or variable. In such cases, the relevant constraint or variable is contained in the quality object as well, unless the constraint has been implicitly created as a result of automatic linearization. Methods are provided to query all information stored in a quality object.

For special considerations about the information available from the solution of a mixed integer programming (MIP) model, see the topic User's Manual: Discrete optimization: Solving mixed integer programming problems (MIP): Using the MIP solution: Accessing information about the MIP solution. See also the topic User's Manual: Discrete optimization: Solving mixed integer programming problems (MIP): Troubleshooting MIP performance problems: MIP kappa: detecting and coping with ill-conditioned MIP models.

For special considerations about the information available from the solution of a model solved by the barrier optimizer, see the topic User's Manual: Continuous optimization: Solving LPs: barrier optimizer: Understanding solution quality from the barrier LP optimizer .

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Quality.GetValue
member.summary: Returns the numeric value of the invoking quality measure.
member.returns: The numeric value of the invoking quality measure.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Quality.GetNumVar
member.summary: Returns the variable at which the quality measure is attained, if any.
member.remarks: Otherwise, null is returned.
member.returns: The variable at which the quality measure is attained.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Quality.GetConstraint
member.summary: Returns the constraint for which the quality measure is attained, if any.
member.remarks: Otherwise, null is returned.
member.returns: The constraint for which the quality measure is attained.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Quality.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string with the numeric value of the invoking quality measure.
member.returns: A string with the numeric value of the invoking quality measure.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Quality.GetQualityType
member.summary: Returns the Cplex.QualityType of the invoking quality measure.
member.returns: The Cplex.QualityType of the invoking quality measure.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.CutType
member.summary: Enumeration of cut types.

remarks.p: Cut types can be used with the method Cplex.GetNcuts to query the cuts in use at the end of the previous mixed integer optimization.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BranchDirection
member.summary: Enumeration of branch direction values.

remarks.p: Branch directions can also be used with the method Cplex.SetDirection and Cplex.SetDirections to select the child node to evaluate first after branching on a specific variable. There are three settings for this purpose:

ul.li: Up: process the child where the lower bound of the variable has been tightened first.
Down: process the child where the upper bound of the variable has been tightened first.
Global: process the child first that the MIP optimizer would have ordinarily chosen.

remarks.p: Branch directions can also be used with the methods Cplex.BranchCallback.MakeBranch to specify branching direction and bounds for an array of variables. The settings have slightly different effects in Cplex.BranchCallback.MakeBranch.

ul.li: Up: set the lower bound of the corresponding variable to the specified bound.
Down: set the upper bound of the corresponding variable to the specified bound.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BranchDirection.Up
member.summary: Upwards branch direction.
member.remarks: Setting this branch direction for a variable instructs Cplex to first process the node where the lower bound has been tightened after branching on that variable.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BranchDirection.Down
member.summary: Downwards branch direction.
member.remarks: Setting this branch direction for a variable instructs Cplex to first process the node where the upper bound has been tightened after branching on that variable.

member.name: F:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BranchDirection.Global
member.summary: Global branch direction.

remarks.p: Setting this branch direction for a variable instructs Cplex to first process the node according to the globally selected or default branch direction.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback
member.summary: The callback base class.

remarks.p: This class defines the common interface available to all callback classes. A callback is an object with a method main implemented by the user. This method is called by the Cplex algorithm at specific points during the optimization. For each of these points, CPLEX provides a context or an extension of Cplex.Callback. To implement and use a particular callback, the user must observe the following steps:

ul.li: Select the callback class corresponding to the callback to be implemented, and create an extension of that class.
Implement the method main for this extension. When doing so, you can use all of the methods defined in the callback class and its base classes.

If the default implementation of the method clone is not adequate, and if the callback is to be used for parallel optimization, this method also needs to be implemented by the user. Recall that the default clone method performs a shallow copy, so typically a user implementation needs to perform a deep copy for objects that should be local to threads or the user implementation must use the synchronize keyword where synchronization is required.
Create an instance of the user-written callback class and pass it to Cplex with the method Cplex.Use.

remarks.p: The next time a solution method is executed on the Cplex object for which the callback has been set, the method main of the callback will be called each time the corresponding point in the optimization algorithm is reached, for example at each iteration.
The methods of this class are protected to make sure they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

This class serves two different purposes:
It is the base class for the legacy callbacks. A legacy callback is implemented by inheritance from any of the descendants of this class and by the user implementation of the main method.
It provides a namespace for the more generic callback that is implemented by implementation of the Function interface (more specifically the Function.Invoke(Cplex.Callback.Context) method) and then using the Context passed into that function to performs queries and actions.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Main
member.summary: The method to be implemented by user callback classes.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Abort
member.summary: Instructs CPLEX to stop the current optimization after the user-written callback finishes.

remarks.p: This method can be called from a user-written implementation of a main method to instruct the invoking CPLEX optimizer to stop the current optimization.

After an invocation of this method, it is possible to resume optimization by another invocation of the method solve. In such a case, optimization continues at the node of the search tree where the abort method was called. In fact, any time that solve stops for a reason other than an error, you can resume optimization by re-invoking solve.

In contrast, executing additional callback methods in the callback can lead to unpredictable behavior. For example, callback methods such as Cplex.SolveCallback.Solve or Cplex.BranchCallback.MakeBranch can overwrite the callback status and thus enable the optimization to continue. Therefore, to abort an optimization effectively, a user should exit the callback by one of the following ways:

ul.li: Call return immediately after the call of abort.
Structure the callback so that it calls no additional methods of Cplex.Callback and its subclasses after abort.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.GetCplexTime
member.summary: Returns a time stamp.

remarks.p: To measure time spent between a starting point and ending point of an operation, take the time stamp at the starting point; take the time stamp at the ending point; subtract the starting time stamp from the ending time stamp to get elapsed time in seconds.
This computation measures either wall clock time (also known as real time) or CPU time, depending on the setting of the clock type parameter ClockType.
The absolute value of the time stamp is not meaningful.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.GetDetTime
member.summary: This method returns a deterministic time stamp in ticks.

remarks.p: To measure deterministic time spent between a starting point and ending point of an operation, take the time stamp at the starting point; take the time stamp at the ending point; subtract the starting time stamp from the ending time stamp to get elapsed time in deterministic ticks.
The absolute value of a deterministic time stamp is not meaningful.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.GetStartTime
member.summary: This method returns a time stamp specifying when the solving process started.

remarks.p: To compute elapsed time in seconds, subtract the result of getCplexTime from the result of this method.
The absolute value of the time stamp is not meaningful.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.GetStartDetTime
member.summary: This method returns a deterministic time stamp specifying when the solving process started.

remarks.p: To compute elapsed time in deterministic ticks, subtract the result of getDetTime from the result of this method.
The absolute value of a deterministic time stamp is not meaningful.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.GetEndTime
member.summary: This method returns a time stamp specifying when solving process terminates.

remarks.p: To compute remaining time in seconds, subtract the result of Cplex.GetCplexTime from the result of this method. This computation yields either wall clock time (also known as real time) or CPU time, depending on the clock type set by the parameter ClockType.
The absolute value of the time stamp is not meaningful.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.GetEndDetTime
member.summary: This method returns a deterministic time stamp specifying when the solving process terminates.

remarks.p: To compute remaining time in deterministic ticks, subtract the result of Cplex.GetDetTime from the result of this method.
The absolute value of the time stamp is not meaningful.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context
member.summary: Context for the CPLEX callback.
member.remarks: Instances of this class describe the context in which the CPLEX callback can be invoked.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetId
member.summary: Gets the context in which the corresponding callback was invoked.
member.returns: A value from Id that specifies the context in which this instance was invoked.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCplex
member.summary: Get the Cplex instance currently running this callback.

remarks.p: The returned Cplex object can be used, for example, to create new constraints that cut off candidate solutions in RejectCandidate.
Important: Do not use anything other than the factory methods of the returned Cplex object. In particular, do not modify this instance. Doing so is unsupported and results in undefined behavior.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.Abort
member.summary: Stops optimization.

remarks.p: This method instructs CPLEX to stop optimization as soon as possible after the callback returns.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.PostHeuristicSolution(ILOG.Concert.INumVar[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.SolutionStrategy)
member.summary: Posts a (heuristic) solution to CPLEX.
member.remarks:
This method posts a solution vector to CPLEX. The vector is queued internally. The next time CPLEX plans to invoke a heuristic, CPLEX looks at the queue and attempts to create feasible solution from each vector. This procedure can result in new incumbent solutions.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.
member.param: Variables that constitute the solution to be posted.
Values for variables in vars.
Index of first variable in vars and vals that constitutes the solution.
Number of variables in vars and vals that constitute the solution.
(Estimated) objective value for the new solution.
Strategy for completing partial solutions.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidatePoint
member.summary: Tests if callback is invoked for a finite solution.

remarks.p: This method can be invoked only from Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.

If the method returns true then the candidate feasible point can be examined using Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidatePoint, Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidateValue, and Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidateObjective.

member.returns: true if the callback was invoked for a candidate feasible point.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidatePoint(ILOG.Concert.INumVar[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method retrieves the values for vars[start], ..., vars[start+length-1] in the current candidate and returns them.
This method can be invoked only from Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate and if Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidatePoint() returns true; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if any error occurs during the query.
member.param: The variables for which values are to be queried.
First variable to query in vars.
Number of variables to query from vars.
member.returns: An array with a value for each variable in vars[start], . . . , vars[start+length-1]. The first value in this array is for vars[start] and so on.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidateRay
member.summary: Tests if callback is invoked for an unbounded relaxation.

remarks.p: This method can be invoked only from Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.
If the method returns true then the unbounded ray can be obtained using Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidateRay().

member.returns: true if the callback was invoked for an unbounded relaxation.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidateRay
member.summary: Gets the unbounded ray for Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate.
member.remarks:
This method returns the unbounded ray as a sparse expression.
This method can be invoked only from Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate and if Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidateRay() returns true; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if any error occurs during the query.
member.returns: An expression representing the ray. Every non-zero coefficient in the ray has the respective non-zero coefficient in the return expression.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidatePoint(ILOG.Concert.INumVar[])
member.summary: Gets the candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method is a convenience wrapper for GetCandidatePoint(INumVar[], int, int). See the reference documentation of that method for further details.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs. Throws NullPointerException if vars or any of its elements is null.
member.param: The variables for which to query the candidate solution.
member.returns: The values for the variables in vars in the candidate solution.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidatePoint(ILOG.Concert.INumVar)
member.summary: Gets the candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method is a convenience wrapper for GetCandidatePoint(INumVar[], int, int). See the reference documentation of that method for further details.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.
member.param: The variable for which to query the candidate solution.
member.returns: The value for var in the candidate solution.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidateValue(ILOG.Concert.INumExpr)
member.summary: Evaluates expr with respect to the current candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method can be invoked only in the context Callback.Context.Id.Candidate and if Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidatePoint() returns true.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs. Throws NullPointerException if expr is null.
member.param: The expression to evaluate.
member.returns: the value of expr with respect to the current candidate solution.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetCandidateObjective
member.summary: Gets the objective of the current candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method can be invoked only from the context Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate and if Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidatePoint() returns true; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.
member.returns: The objective value of the current candidate solution.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.RejectCandidate(ILOG.Concert.IRange[])
member.summary: Rejects the current candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method can be invoked only from Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Candidate and if Cplex.Callback.Context.IsCandidatePoint() returns true; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.
The argument of this method consists of a set of constraints that CPLEX treats as lazy constraints.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs. Throws NullPointerException if any of the elements in violated is null.
member.param: A set of constraints that cut off the candidate solution. This set can potentially be empty. This argument can also be null. If not null and not empty, then CPLEX can use these constraints to cut off further candidate solutions that CPLEX finds. (There is no guarantee that CPLEX does so, though.)

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.RejectCandidate(ILOG.Concert.IRange)
member.summary: Rejects the current candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method is a convenience wrapper for RejectCandidate(IRange[]).
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.
member.param: A constraint that cuts of the candidate solution. This argument can be null.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.RejectCandidate
member.summary: Rejects the current candidate solution.
member.remarks:
This method is a convenience wrapper for RejectCandidate(IRange[]). With this you can reject the current candidate solution without adding a constraint that cuts it off.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if an error occurs.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.GetRelaxationPoint(ILOG.Concert.INumVar[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the current relaxation.
member.remarks:
This method retrieves the values for vars[start], . . . , vars[start+length-1] in the current relaxation, and returns them.
This method can be invoked only from Cplex.Callback.Context.Id.Relaxation; it throws an exception when invoked from another context.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception if any error occurs during the query.
member.param: The variables for which relaxation values are to be queried.
First variable to query in vars.
Number of variables to query from vars.
member.returns: An array with a value for each variable in vars[start], . . . , vars[start+length-1]. The first value in this array is for vars[start] and so on.

Number of variables to query from vars.
member.returns: An array with a value for each variable in vars[start], . . . , vars[start+length-1]. The first value in this array is for vars[start] and so on.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context.Id
member.summary: Places in which a CPLEX callback can be invoked.

remarks.p:
The values defined here specify in which contexts CPLEX can invoke a callback. They are used in two different ways:
The are used as arguments to Callback.Function.Invoke to indicate in which context the callback has just been invoked.
A bit-wise OR of these values is used as argument to Cplex.Use(Callback.Function, long) to specify in which places CPLEX should invoke the registered callback.
For details about the various context values, refer to Callback context in the Reference Manual of the Callable Library (C API) for further details about these values. reference documentation.
Important notes about the ThreadDown context:

ul.li: If a callback invoked in ThreadUp context throws an exception then ThreadDown will not be invoked on this thread!
The callback function is not allowed to throw exceptions if invoked in context ThreadDown. Any exception thrown in this context will be ignored.

remarks.p: You may think of ThreadUp and ThreadDown as "constructor" and "destructor": the destructor is only invoked if the object was fully constructed and is not allowed to throw an exception.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Function
member.summary: Interface for CPLEX callbacks.

remarks.p: Any class to be used as a CPLEX callback must implement this interface. See the documentation of Cplex.Use(Callback.Function, long) for more details.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Function.Invoke(ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.Callback.Context)
member.summary: Invokes the CPLEX callback.
member.remarks:
If an object is registered with CPLEX by means of Cplex.Use(Callback.Function, long), then CPLEX will invoke this function of the registered object in all contexts requested by the contextMask passed to Cplex.Use(Callback.Function, long).
Note that in this function you must not invoke any functions of the Cplex instance that is performing the current solve. All functions that can be invoked from a callback are members of context.
Throws ILOG.Concert.Exception in order to indicate any sort of error.
member.param: An instance of Callback.Context that defines in which context the callback is invoked, which progress information can be queried, and which actions can be performed. This instance is valid only during execution of the callback function. The user must not keep a reference to it.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback
member.summary: The callback base class for user-written callbacks invoked at every iteration of the simplex or barrier optimizers when they are solving a continuous model.

remarks.p: Continuous callbacks are executed at every iteration of the simplex algorithm or the barrier algorithm during the solution of a continuous model. Algorithm-specific callbacks are also available in the extensions Cplex.SimplexCallback and Cplex.BarrierCallback. By setting a continuous callback with the method Cplex.Use, you set the same callback for both the simplex and the barrier callback, thus potentially overriding other previously installed callbacks of these types.
In the case of concurrent optimization, CPLEX calls the user-written callback only in the main thread, not in other concurrent threads.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.#ctor
member.summary: The user-written callback constructor.
member.remarks: This constructor can be called only to construct objects of derived user-written callback classes, not to construct Cplex.ContinuousCallback objects directly.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.GetObjValue
member.summary: Returns the current objective value.
member.remarks: The current objective value is the objective value at the point when the callback is called. In the simplex method, this objective value may not reflect the objective function defined for the model being solved, but an artificial phase 1 objective function used to achieve primal or dual feasibility. In the barrier method, where the objective functions can be computed using dual or primal vectors and both definitions are not equivalent (unless optimality is achieved), the primal objective function is returned.
member.returns: The current objective value.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.GetInfeasibility
member.summary: Returns a measure for the primal infeasibility of the current solution.
member.remarks: If the current solution is primal feasible, a value of 0 will be returned. Otherwise a positive value will be returned.
member.returns: A measure for the primal infeasibility of the current solution.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.GetDualInfeasibility
member.summary: Returns a measure for the dual infeasibility of the current solution.
member.remarks: If the current solution is dual feasible, a value of 0 will be returned. Otherwise a positive value will be returned.
member.returns: A measure for the dual infeasibility of the current solution.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.IsFeasible
member.summary: Returns a Boolean value reporting whether the current solution is primal feasible.
member.returns: A Boolean value reporting whether the current solution is primal feasible.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.IsDualFeasible
member.summary: Returns a Boolean value reporting whether the current solution is dual feasible.
member.returns: A Boolean value reporting whether the current solution is dual feasible.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.GetNiterations
member.summary: Returns the number of iterations performed so far.
member.returns: The number of iterations performed so far.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ContinuousCallback.GetNiterations64
member.summary: Returns the number of iterations performed so far.
member.returns: The number of iterations performed so far.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.SimplexCallback
member.summary: This is the callback class to use when Cplex uses the simplex optimizer.

remarks.p: An instance of this class represents a user-written callback in an application that uses an instance of Cplex to solve a problem by means of the (primal or dual) simplex optimizer. For more information on the simplex optimizers, see the CPLEX User's Manual.
Cplex calls the user-written callback at the end of each simplex iteration.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.SimplexCallback.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor for a user-written simplex callback.
member.remarks: This constructor can be called only to construct objects of derived user-written callback classes, but not to construct Cplex.SimplexCallback objects directly.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BarrierCallback
member.summary: This is the callback class to use when Cplex uses the barrier optimizer.

remarks.p: This class represents a user-written callback in an application that uses an instance of Cplex to solve a problem by means of the barrier optimizer. Cplex calls the user-written callback at the end of each barrier iteration. If an attempt is made to access information not available to an instance of this class, an exception is thrown.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BarrierCallback.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor for user-written barrier callback.
member.remarks: This constructor can be called only to construct objects of derived user-written callback classes. It cannot be used to construct Cplex.BarrierCallback objects directly.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.BarrierCallback.GetDualObjValue

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.NetworkCallback
member.summary: This is the callback class to use when Cplex uses the network optimizer.

remarks.p: An instance of the class NetCallback represents a user-written callback in an application that uses an instance of Cplex with the network optimizer. The callback is executed each time the network optimizer issues a log file message.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.NetworkCallback.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor for user-written network callback.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.NetworkCallback.GetObjValue
member.summary: Returns the current objective value.
member.remarks: The current objective value is the objective value at the point when the callback is called. In the network simplex method, this objective value may not reflect the objective function defined for the model being solved, but an artificial phase 1 objective function used to achieve primal feasibility. Also, since the network optimizer sees only the embedded network part of the full model, the objective value may not reflect the objective function of the full model.
member.returns: The current objective function value.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.NetworkCallback.GetInfeasibility
member.summary: Returns the primal infeasibility measure at the moment the callback is called.
member.remarks: If primal feasibility is obtained, the value 0 is returned. Otherwise, this method returns a positive value. Since the network optimizer sees only the embedded network part of the full model, a solution considered to be feasible for the network optimizer may not be so for the full model.
member.returns: The measure of primal infeasibility.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.NetworkCallback.IsFeasible
member.summary: Returns a Boolean value reporting whether the current solution is primal feasible at the moment the callback is called.
member.remarks: Since the network optimizer sees only the embedded network part of the full model, a solution considered to be feasible for the network optimizer may not be so for the full model.
member.returns: A Boolean value reporting whether the current solution is primal feasible.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPInfoCallback
member.summary: The base class for all MIP informational callbacks.

remarks.p: An instance of the class MIPInfoCallback represents a user-written callback in an application that uses an instance of Cplex to solve a mixed integer program (MIP). Cplex calls the user-written callback prior to solving each node in the branch-and-cut search.
User-written callbacks of this class are compatible with dynamic search.

This class allows you to access an incumbent solution, an incumbent node, and an incumbent objective value from a user-written callback. It also allows you to access priority orders and statistical information, such as the number of cuts that have been generated. Methods are also available to query the number of generated cuts for each type of cut CPLEX generates. See the CPLEX User's Manual for more information about cuts.
This class provides a common application programming interface (API) for these subclasses:

ul.li: Cplex.MIPCallback and its extensions.

remarks.p: The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

The user-written callback of this class is called by only one thread, even in the case of parallel execution. Consequently, it is not necessary for the user-written callback to manage synchronization.

summary.p: Constructor for user-written MIP informational callback.
This constructor can be called only to construct objects of derived user-written callback classes, but not to construct MIPInfoCallback objects directly.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPInfoCallback.GetBestObjValue
member.summary: This method returns a bound on the optimal solution value of the active problem at the moment the callback is called.
member.remarks:
When a model has been solved to optimality, this value matches the optimal solution value. Before optimality has been proven, this value is computed for a minimization (maximization) problem as the minimum (maximum) objective function value of all remaining unexplored nodes.
ILOG.Concert.Exception If the method fails, an exception of type ILOG.Concert.Exception, or one of its derived classes, is thrown.
member.returns: A bound on the optimal solution value.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPInfoCallback.GetMIPRelativeGap
member.summary: This method returns the relative objective gap of the active problem at the moment the callback is called.

remarks.p:
For a minimization problem, this value is computed by
(bestinteger - bestobjective) / (1e-10 + |bestinteger|)
where bestinteger is the value returned by Cplex.GetObjValue and bestobjective is the value returned by Cplex.GetBestObjValue. For a maximization problem, the value is computed by:
(bestobjective - bestinteger) / (1e-10 + |bestinteger|)
remarks.exception: ILOG.Concert.Exception If the method fails, an exception of type ILOG.Concert.Exception, or one of its derived classes, is thrown.

member.returns: The relative objective gap.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPInfoCallback.GetCutoff
member.summary: Returns the cutoff for the objective value when nodes are being solved during branch-and-cut search.
member.remarks: This value is typically computed from the objective value of an incumbent solution and the optimality gap. In the case of a minimization problem, for example, if the objective value of a node exceeds the cutoff value, the node can be pruned without the need to solve the node to optimality.
member.returns: The objective value cutoff.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPInfoCallback.GetIncumbentObjValue

summary.p: Returns the objective value of the current best integer solution at the moment the callback is called.
This method returns the objective value for the current incumbent solution (that is, the best integer solution found so far).
If there is no incumbent, this method returns a very large positive number for a minimization or a very small negative number for a maximization.

member.returns: The objective value for the current incumbent solution.

member.param: The variable whose incumbent solution value is being queried.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.MIPCallback
member.summary: The base class for MIP control and query callbacks.

remarks.p: An instance of the class MIPCallback represents a user-written callback in an application that uses an instance of Cplex to solve a mixed integer program (MIP). Cplex calls the user-written callback prior to solving each node in the branch-and-cut search. This class allows you to access an incumbent solution, an incumbent node, and an incumbent objective value from a user-written callback. It also allows you to access priority orders and statistical information, such as the number of cuts that have been generated. Methods are also available to query the number of generated cuts for each type of cut CPLEX generates. See the CPLEX User's Manual for more information about cuts.
This class also provides a common application programming interface (API) for these subclasses of control and query callbacks:

ul.li:
Cplex.ControlCallback with its extensions:
Cplex.BranchCallback
Cplex.HeuristicCallback
Cplex.UserCutCallback
Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback
Cplex.SolveCallback

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.IncumbentCallback
member.summary: Class of callbacks called when a new incumbent is found.

remarks.p: This is an advanced class.

Advanced classes typically demand a profound understanding of the algorithms used by CPLEX. Thus they incur a higher risk of incorrect behavior in your application, behavior that can be difficult to debug. Therefore, the team encourages you to consider carefully whether you can accomplish the same task by means of other classes instead.

An instance of this callback class is called whenever a new potential incumbent is found during the branch-and-cut search. It allows you to analyze the proposed incumbent and optionally reject it. In this case, CPLEX will continue the branch-and-cut search. However, since CPLEX considers the current node solution to be integer feasible, it will not be able to determine a reasonable way to branch. Thus, when this callback is implemented in such a way that it may reject an incumbent, it is typically paired with a branch callback to perform the branching after an incumbent has been rejected.

When you use this callback to reject an incumbent, you must set the parameter to control the type of primal and dual reductions, Cplex.IntParam.Reduce either to 1 (one) in order to restrict presolve to primal reductions only, or to 0 (zero) in order to disable all presolve reductions. This setting of the reduction parameter is not necessary if the incumbent callback is used for other purposes.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

The incumbent callback may be invoked during MIP start processing. In that case, {@link Cplex.IncumbentCallback#getSolutionSource() Cplex.IncumbentCallback.GetSolutionSource()} will return MIPStartSolution. In this situation, the following special consideration applies:
MIP start processing occurs very early in the solution process. At this point no search tree is setup yet and there are no search tree nodes yet. Consequently, a lot of the callback functions that require a node context will fail in this situation.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.SolveCallback
member.summary: The base class for user-written solve callbacks to control how subproblems (for example, node and heuristic subproblems) are solved within branch and cut.

remarks.p: An instance of this class can be used to solve subproblems during a branch-and-cut search. It allows you to set a starting point when a node is being solved or to select the solution algorithm on a per-node basis.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ControlCallback
member.summary: Base class for all callback classes querying or taking control of the MIP branch-and-cut search.

remarks.p: This is an advanced class.

Advanced classes typically demand a profound understanding of the algorithms used by CPLEX. Thus they incur a higher risk of incorrect behavior in your application, behavior that can be difficult to debug. Therefore, the team encourages you to consider carefully whether you can accomplish the same task by means of other classes instead.
This is the base class for all callback classes that allow you to query or take control of the MIP branch-and-cut search. These classes are:

ul.li: Cplex.BranchCallback
Cplex.HeuristicCallback
Cplex.UserCutCallback
Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback
Cplex.SolveCallback

remarks.p: An instance of ControlCallback is not a callback for implementing user functionality itself, but rather provides the common interface for those listed callback classes. Those callbacks share the property that they are called at every node in the branch-and-cut search tree, and allow you to access node-related data. For each branch-and-cut node, those callbacks are called in the following order:

ol.li: Cplex.UserCutCallback: Once the node problem has been solved and Cplex has added all its cuts, the user cut callback is called. In case new cuts are added to the problem, the node problem is solved again. This is iterated until no more cuts are added to the problem.

Cplex.HeuristicCallback: Once the node has been fully solved (that is including all the cuts that may have been added), the heuristic callback is called in an attempt to generate an integer feasible solution from the current relaxation solution at that node.

Cplex.BranchCallback: Finally, if the relaxation solution at the current node is either integer infeasible or rejected by the Cplex.IncumbentCallback, the problem is split into subproblems. At that point the Cplex.BranchCallback can be used to control how to create the subproblems.

remarks.p: The methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

In the case where the node LP is unbounded, the methods getValue return a vector that corresponds to an unbounded direction. The vector is scaled in such a way that the maximum absolute value of one of its elements is CPX_INFBOUND. Thus, often the vector can be used directly, for example to separate lazy constraints. However, due to the large values, care must be taken to deal with potential numerical errors. If in doubt, rescale the vector, and use it as an unbounded ray rather than as a primal vector.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ControlCallback.GetNodeId

summary.p: Returns the node identifier of the current node.

member.returns: the Cplex.NodeId of the current node.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ControlCallback.GetLB(ILOG.Concert.INumVar)
member.summary: Returns the current lower bound for the variable var.
member.remarks: This bound may be different from the bound the variable has in the active model, since branching or bound strengthening may have been applied to it. The corresponding solution value from getValue may violate this bound at a node where a new incumbent has been found because the bound is tightened when an incumbent is found.
member.param: The variable whose current lower bound is being queried.

member.summary: Instructs Cplex to use a solution.

remarks.p: This method instructs Cplex to use the solution generated with this callback instead of solving the node itself.
If useSolution is not called, Cplex uses the algorithm selected with the parameter Cplex.IntParam.RootAlg or Cplex.IntParam.NodeAlg to solve the node.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.SolveCallback.SetStart(System.Double[],ILOG.Concert.INumVar[],System.Double[],ILOG.Concert.IRange[])
member.summary: Specifies a starting point for the next invocation of the method solve during the current solve callback.

remarks.p: Starting point information is exploited at the next call of the method solve before the termination of the SolveCallback.Main function currently being executed. In particular, if the node is being solved with the simplex optimizer, the starting point information provided with this method is used to construct a starting basis for the simplex optimizer.

The starting point information is provided in the arguments of this method. NULL can be passed for any of the arguments. However, if x is not NULL, var must not be NULL. Similarly, if pi is not NULL, rng must not be NULL.

member.summary: The cut is added to the relaxation and remains there.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback
member.summary: Callback class for lazy constraints.

remarks.p: This is an advanced class.

Advanced classes typically demand a profound understanding of the algorithms used by CPLEX. Thus they incur a higher risk of incorrect behavior in your application, behavior that can be difficult to debug. Therefore, the team encourages you to consider carefully whether you can accomplish the same task by means of other classes instead.

This is the lazy constraint callback class. Extensions of this class implement user-written lazy constraint callbacks. These allow you to add lazy constraints to the problem while the problem is being solved with branch-and-cut search. These lazy constraints may contribute to the model formulation and restrict the feasible region of the problem. By contrast, if a constraint to be added during branch-and-cut search does not change the feasible region of the active model but only strengthens the formulation, it is referred to as a user cut. Such constraints should better be added through Cplex.UserCutCallback because this distinction allows Cplex potentially to perform more presolve reductions. It is an error, however, to add lazy constraints by means of a user cut callback.

The idea behind lazy constraints is that the LPs that are solved when the MIP is being solved can be kept smaller when these constraints are not included. Cplex will, however, include a lazy constraint in the LP as soon as it becomes violated. In other words, the solution computed by Cplex makes sure that all the lazy constraints that have been added are satisfied.

If you use LazyConstraintCallback, you are free to add cuts that may chop off solutions that are otherwise feasible with respect to the model, in contrast to UserCutCallback. In the case of UserCutCallback, you effectively promise CPLEX that you are not adding cuts that reduce the solution space by the callback.

When you query information about the current solution to be tested, such information may be different from information directly derived from the node relaxation. Such differences arise when the solution candidate to be tested is generated from a heuristic rather than the branch-and-bound tree itself.

The lazy constraint callback may be invoked during MIP start processing. In that case, {@link Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback#getSolutionSource() Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback.GetSolutionSource()} returns MIPStartSolution. When this value is returned, some special considerations apply:
MIP start processing occurs very early in the solution process. At this point no search tree is setup yet and there are no search tree nodes yet. Consequently, a lot of the callback functions that require a node context will fail in this situation.
Lazy constraints separated when processing a MIP start will be discarded after that MIP start has been processed. This means that the callback may have to separate the same constraint again for the next MIP start or for a solution that is found later in the solution process.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback.Add(ILOG.Concert.IRange)
member.summary: Adds cut as a global lazy constraint to the problem being solved.
member.remarks: As a lazy constraint, this cut must be globally valid. It will not be removed by backtracking or any other means during the search.
member.param: The constraint to be added as a global lazy constraint. The constraint must be linear.
member.returns: The lazy constraint that has been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback.Add(ILOG.Concert.IRange,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds cut as a global lazy constraint to the problem being solved.

remarks.p: As a lazy constraint, this cut must be globally valid.
Possible values for the argument cutmanagement are documented in Cplex.CutManagement with the following considerations:

li.p: For lazy constraints, a value of UseCutFilter is not valid and prompts an exception to be thrown.

A value of UseCutPurge authorizes CPLEX to purge (that is, eliminate) the lazy constraint under certain circumstances (for example, if the constraint becomes slack). Consequently, in view of such purging, the user must not assume that any previously added constraints are still in the current relaxation. In other words, the purged constraint may be violated in subsequent relaxations, and the user must take responsibility to check whether any new incumbent solution requires that the purged lazy constraint be added back to the model.

A value of UseCutForce perpetually retains the cut after it has been added as a lazy constraint. This value is equivalent to a call of the add method with only a single argument (that is, the cut to be added as a lazy constraint).

member.param: The constraint to be added as a global lazy constraint. The constraint must be linear.
An integer indicating how the lazy constraint should be managed by CPLEX. Possible values are listed in Cplex.CutManagement.
member.returns: The lazy constraint that has been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback.AddLocal(ILOG.Concert.IRange)
member.summary: Adds cut as a local lazy constraint to the problem being solved.

remarks.p: This lazy constraint will not be removed when the search backtracks. In other words, it is active only for the subtree rooted at the invoking node.

member.param: The constraint to be added as a local lazy constraint. The constraint must be linear.
member.returns: The lazy constraint that has been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback.GetSolutionSource

Note that lazy constraint callbacks are not invoked for solutions provided by a heuristic callback. So a value of Cplex.SolutionSource.UserSolution will never be returned.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.UserCutCallback
member.summary: This is the callback class to use to add user-written cuts during the branch-and-cut search.

remarks.p: This is an advanced class.

Advanced classes typically demand a profound understanding of the algorithms used by CPLEX. Thus they incur a higher risk of incorrect behavior in your application, behavior that can be difficult to debug. Therefore, the team encourages you to consider carefully whether you can accomplish the same task by means of other classes instead.

This is the user cut callback class. Extensions of this class implement user-written user cut callbacks. They allow you to add user cuts to the problem while the problem is being solved with branch-and-cut search. User cuts may not contribute to the model formulation; user cuts must not restrict the feasible region of the problem, but only strengthen the formulation. If constraints that do restrict the feasible region of the problem are to be added during the optimization, an instance of Cplex.LazyConstraintCallback must be used instead. Cuts are added from this callback by a call to the method add. The added cuts must be globally valid because they are not removed automatically during backtracking.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

When you use UserCutCallback, you effectively promise CPLEX that you are not adding cuts that reduce the solution space by the callback, in contrast to LazyConstraintCallback. By using UserCutCallback, you allow CPLEX to pursue presolve more aggressively. In the case of LazyConstraintCallback, you are free to add cuts that may chop off solutions that are otherwise feasible with respect to the model.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.UserCutCallback.Add(ILOG.Concert.IRange,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds cut as a global user cut to the problem being solved.

remarks.p: This cut must be globally valid. The cut must also not cut off any solution. The cut will not be removed by backtracking. If you designate the cut as purgeable, then CPLEX can remove the cut under certain conditions.

member.param: The constraint to be added as a global cut. The constraint must be linear.
An integer indicating how the cut should be managed by CPLEX. Possible values are listed in Cplex.CutManagement.
member.returns: The cut that has been added.

member.name: M:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.UserCutCallback.AddLocal(ILOG.Concert.IRange)
member.summary: Adds its argument as a local cut to the problem being solved.

remarks.p: This cut will not be removed when the search backtracks. In other words, it is active only for the subtree rooted at the invoking node.

member.param: The constraint to be added as a local cut. The constraint must be linear.
member.returns: The cut that has been added.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.ProbingInfoCallback
member.summary: Monitors probing progress for user-written callbacks in a mixed integer program (MIP).

remarks.p: User-written callbacks of this class are compatible with dynamic search.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

The user-written callback of this class is called by only one thread, even in the case of parallel execution. Consequently, it is not necessary for the user-written callback to manage synchronization.

member.name: T:ILOG.CPLEX.Cplex.FractionalCutInfoCallback
member.summary: Monitors the progress of the generation of fractional cuts when a mixed integer programming problem (MIP) is being solved.

remarks.p: An instance of this class represents a user-written callback in an application that uses an instance of Cplex to solve a mixed integer programming problem (a MIP). It allows you to monitor the progress of the generation of fractional cuts.
User-written callbacks of this class are compatible with dynamic search.
The constructor and methods of this class are protected to make sure that they are used only to derive a user-written callback class or to implement the main method in it.

The user-written callback of this class is called by only one thread, even in the case of parallel execution. Consequently, it is not necessary for the user-written callback to manage synchronization.
